questions.question: This UNESCO site in Southern Europe, recognized in 1981, is renowned for its Byzantine mosaics. It served as a major political and cultural center in the Greek world.
questions.context: Olympia is the birthplace of the Olympic Games, held every four years beginning in 8th century BC.

questions.question: Known for its vibrant and unique space design, this modern architectural marvel houses one of Asia's most significant financial hubs.
questions.context: Opened in 2010, the hotel is famous for its infinity pool and SkyPark located on the 57th floor.

questions.question: This historical battle site in the Middle East witnessed a crucial confrontation during the Crusades in 1187, leading to a significant territorial change.
questions.context: The battle led by Saladin led to the fall of most of the Crusader Kingdom of Jerusalem.

questions.question: A dark tourism site, this infamous location has been preserved as a memorial to the victims of one of history's most tragic nuclear events, which occurred in 1986.
questions.context: Chernobyl has become a symbol of nuclear disaster and the catastrophic consequences of human and technological failure.

questions.question: In this ancient ruin located in the Americas, visitors can explore a pre-Columbian city that is an important archaeological site of the Maya civilization dating back to 600 AD.
questions.context: Tikal was once a powerful city-state and is famous for its towering pyramids amidst dense rainforest.
